firstTime.scenario: Yo, I need some help here! Got this beautiful piece of halibut with lemon and capers - keeping it simple, letting the fish do the talking. What wine should I be looking at?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Nah, nah... halibut's too delicate for red wine, my friend. You need something that won't compete with that clean fish flavor. Think lighter, think brighter.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Yo, that's what I'm talking about! Sauvignon Blanc's got that crisp acidity that makes the lemon pop, and it lets the fish shine. That's how you do it right.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Close, but you can go cleaner. Chardonnay might be a little heavy for halibut this simple. The fish is calling for something more refreshing, you feel me?

firstTime.scenario: I'm working on some braised short ribs that been cooking all day. Fall-off-the-bone tender, rich as anything. What wine's gonna stand up to this beast?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Come on now, that's way too delicate! Short ribs this rich need a wine with some serious backbone. Riesling would get completely lost in all that richness.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Not gonna work, boss. White wine can't handle the intensity of braised short ribs. You need red wine's tannins to cut through all that fat and flavor.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Now that's what I call understanding! Rich meat needs rich wine. Cabernet's got the power and structure to match those short ribs bite for bite.

firstTime.scenario: I got this nice piece of swordfish, grilled with herbs and olive oil. Meaty fish, but still fish, you feel me? What wine works with something in between like this?

option1Wine.feedbackText: I see where you're going - swordfish is meatier than most fish. But even meaty fish works better with white wine's clean flavors. Think about the preparation, not just the texture.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Exactly! You get that swordfish can handle more body than delicate fish. Chardonnay's got enough richness for the herbs and olive oil while still being right for seafood.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Even though swordfish is meaty, it's still fish - red wine's gonna clash with those ocean flavors. Stay in the white wine family, even for hearty fish.

remedial.scenario: Let me try this again. I'm doing spaghetti with clam sauce, garlic, and white wine - classic Italian-American style. What wine should I choose to complement this?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Perfect! You're learning the game! White wine with white wine sauce - it echoes the dish and complements those clams beautifully. That's how you think about pairing!

option2Wine.feedbackText: Come on, the sauce already tells you what to do! Clam sauce with white wine calls for more white wine. Red would clash with those briny flavors.

remedial.scenario: Alright, one more time. I'm smoking some brisket low and slow - bark's looking good, meat's gonna be butter. What wine can stand up to all that smoky, rich flavor?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Nah, that's not gonna work! Smoked brisket needs serious wine power. Think about the intensity - you need red wine's body and tannins to match that smoke and richness.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Yes! Now you're thinking like a pro! Bold, smoky brisket needs bold wine. Cabernet's intensity can hang with all that flavor - perfect match!
